questions.questionText: What federal law prohibits employment discrimination based on protected classes?
options: A) Fair Housing Act
B) Civil Rights Act of 1964
C) Equal Credit Opportunity Act
D) Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act
questions.explanation: The Civil Rights Act of 1964 prohibits employment discrimination based on protected classes like race, sex, and religion.

questions.questionText: What agency enforces federal employment discrimination laws?
options: A) DSPS
B) Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC)
C) Wisconsin Department of Workforce Development (DWD)
D) National Labor Relations Board (NLRB)
questions.explanation: The EEOC investigates complaints and enforces federal employment discrimination law.

questions.questionText: What must a written independent contractor agreement for licensees include for federal tax purposes?
options: A) A guarantee of hourly pay
B) A statement that the licensee will not be treated as an employee for tax purposes
C) A non-compete clause
D) A statement regarding commission-sharing percentages
questions.explanation: Federal tax law requires this statement in written independent contractor agreements.

questions.questionText: Which of the following is considered a protected class under Wisconsin law but not federal law?
options: A) Race
B) Religion
C) Sexual orientation
D) Disability
questions.explanation: Wisconsin law includes sexual orientation as a protected class.

questions.questionText: What type of assistant may engage in real estate practice on behalf of a firm?
options: A) Licensed personal assistant
B) Unlicensed personal assistant
C) Independent contractor assistant
D) General office assistant
questions.explanation: Licensed personal assistants can perform duties requiring a real estate license.

questions.questionText: What type of compensation arrangement requires the licensee to pay a desk fee to the firm?
options: A) Commission sharing
B) 100% commission
C) Salary
D) Profit sharing
questions.explanation: In a 100% commission structure, agents pay a desk fee to cover overhead costs.

questions.questionText: What is the required retention period for lead-based paint disclosure documents?
options: A) Two years
B) Three years
C) Five years
D) Seven years
questions.explanation: Federal law mandates a three-year retention period for these documents.

questions.questionText: What is the statute of limitations for bringing legal action against a real estate licensee in Wisconsin?
options: A) One year
B) Two years
C) Three years
D) Five years
questions.explanation: The statute of limitations for such actions is two years.

questions.questionText: What is the minimum age requirement to obtain a real estate license in Wisconsin?
questions.explanation: Applicants must be at least 18 years old.

questions.questionText: What is the biennial license renewal deadline for Wisconsin real estate licenses?
options: A) December 14 of odd-numbered years
B) December 14 of even-numbered years
C) June 30 of odd-numbered years
D) June 30 of even-numbered years
questions.explanation: Wisconsin licenses expire on December 14 of every even-numbered year.

questions.questionText: Who must approve a broker's independent practice outside of the firm?
options: A) DSPS
B) Local board of REALTORS®
C) The broker’s supervising firm
D) The firm’s clients
questions.explanation: Written approval from the supervising firm is required.

questions.questionText: What is a firm’s primary responsibility under Wis. Stat. § 452.132?
options: A) Ensure compliance with advertising laws
B) Supervise the brokerage service activities of licensees
C) Determine commission-sharing arrangements
D) Set fair housing policies
questions.explanation: Firms are responsible for supervising licensee activities.

questions.questionText: What document should a licensee provide to clients after signing an agency agreement?
options: A) A copy of the firm’s policy manual
B) A copy of the signed agency agreement
C) A receipt for earnest money
D) A disclosure of closing costs
questions.explanation: Licensees must provide signed copies of agency agreements promptly.

questions.questionText: How long must Wisconsin real estate firms retain transaction documents?
options: A) One year
B) Two years
C) Three years
D) Five years
questions.explanation: Firms must retain documents for at least two years.

questions.questionText: What federal law requires reasonable accommodations for disabilities in public accommodations?
options: A) Fair Housing Act
B) Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA)
C) Civil Rights Act of 1964
D) Equal Credit Opportunity Act
questions.explanation: The ADA sets standards for accessibility in public accommodations.

questions.questionText: What does the IRS require for a real estate agent to be classified as an independent contractor?
options: A) The agent must earn at least 50% of income from commissions
B) The agent must have a written agreement stating independent contractor status for tax purposes
C) The agent must work under a desk fee arrangement
D) The agent must receive only bonuses
questions.explanation: IRS regulations require a written agreement for independent contractor classification.

questions.questionText: Which document establishes the firm’s procedures for handling transaction documents?
options: A) Policy Manual
B) Listing Agreement
C) Agency Agreement
D) Code of Ethics
questions.explanation: The policy manual outlines the firm’s procedures for handling documents and records.

questions.questionText: What is the consequence for failing to renew a real estate license on time in Wisconsin?
options: A) A suspension for six months
B) Prohibition from practicing real estate until renewal is complete
C) Immediate revocation of the license
D) A requirement to retake the licensing exam
questions.explanation: A licensee cannot practice real estate until the license is renewed.

questions.questionText: Under what condition can a salesperson begin working with a new firm?
options: A) After submitting the DSPS notice of transfer
B) After receiving verbal permission from the previous firm
C) Only after the license is physically transferred
D) After signing a new agency agreement
questions.explanation: The salesperson must notify the DSPS of the transfer and pay the required fee.

questions.questionText: What is the retention period for trust account records?
options: A) Two years
B) Three years
C) Five years
D) Ten years
questions.explanation: Trust account records must be kept for at least two years from the date of the transaction’s closure.

questions.questionText: How should a firm handle architectural barriers under the ADA if removal is not feasible?
options: A) Ignore the barriers
B) Use alternative methods to provide access
C) Apply for an exemption from compliance
D) Limit services to accessible areas only
questions.explanation: Firms must offer alternative methods, such as meeting clients in accessible locations, if barrier removal is not readily achievable.

questions.questionText: What must a supervising broker review before closing a transaction?
options: A) Trust account balances only
B) All transaction documents and trust account records
C) Only the agency agreements
D) The buyer’s financial statements
questions.explanation: Supervising brokers must review transaction documents and trust account records for accuracy and compliance.

questions.questionText: What distinguishes a licensed personal assistant from an unlicensed assistant?
options: A) Licensed assistants can engage in real estate practice
B) Licensed assistants must work for multiple agents
C) Licensed assistants can only perform clerical duties
D) Licensed assistants are not subject to firm supervision
questions.explanation: Licensed personal assistants are permitted to engage in activities requiring a real estate license.

questions.questionText: What is the two-year statute of limitations for legal action against licensees based on?
options: A) The closing date or termination of an agency agreement
B) The first client meeting
C) The date the licensee became licensed
D) The date the licensee was notified of the issue
questions.explanation: The statute begins at the earlier of the closing or agency agreement termination.

questions.questionText: What must a firm do before hiring an unlicensed personal assistant?
options: A) File a notification with the DSPS
B) Sign an agreement with the hiring licensee
C) Ensure the assistant takes continuing education
D) Obtain approval from the local board of REALTORS®
questions.explanation: The firm must sign an agreement with the hiring licensee outlining duties and supervision.

questions.questionText: What is the penalty for failing to notify the DSPS of a name or address change within 30 days?
options: A) Suspension of the license
B) Fine and warning
C) Revocation of the license
D) Increased renewal fees
questions.explanation: Failure to notify the DSPS can lead to license suspension.

questions.questionText: How is commission-sharing typically calculated?
options: A) As a flat rate per transaction
B) As a percentage of the firm’s commission
C) Based on hours worked
D) Based on client reviews
questions.explanation: Commission-sharing is a percentage of the firm’s total commission for a transaction.

questions.questionText: What must a broker include in a transition plan for trust accounts?
options: A) Account balances only
B) A list of authorized signatories and record locations
C) Client addresses
D) Instructions for closing the accounts immediately
questions.explanation: Transition plans should detail authorized signatories, account locations, and record access.

questions.questionText: Who enforces Wisconsin’s employment discrimination laws?
options: A) EEOC
B) DSPS
C) Department of Workforce Development (DWD)
D) Attorney General
questions.explanation: The DWD investigates and enforces state employment discrimination laws.

questions.questionText: What must a firm’s supervising broker ensure for every associated licensee?
options: A) Access to a local real estate association
B) Proper licensing and compliance with rules
C) Payment of licensing fees by the firm
D) Use of independent contractor agreements only
questions.explanation: Supervising brokers must ensure that all associated licensees are properly licensed and compliant.

questions.questionText: When does a firm’s liability for misrepresentation by a subagent apply?
options: A) Only if the firm directly participated in the misrepresentation
B) If the firm knew or should have known about the misrepresentation
C) Always, regardless of the firm’s knowledge
D) Never, as subagents are fully independent
questions.explanation: A firm is liable for a subagent’s misrepresentation only if it knew or should have known about it.

questions.questionText: What element distinguishes strict responsibility misrepresentation from other types?
options: A) Intent to deceive
B) Negligence in verifying facts
C) Public policy favoring the buyer over the licensee
D) The licensee’s lack of economic interest in the transaction
questions.explanation: Strict responsibility prioritizes public policy by holding the firm liable even if the licensee acted innocently.

questions.questionText: How must a supervising broker communicate document errors to a licensee?
options: A) Verbally and without documentation
B) By directly informing the client
C) Through formal communication with the licensee
D) Via DSPS reporting channels
questions.explanation: The supervising broker must formally communicate errors to the licensee for corrective action.

questions.questionText: What does a Wisconsin licensee need to do after a criminal conviction?
options: A) Submit a copy of the judgment and details to the DSPS within 48 hours
B) Notify their firm and clients immediately
C) Wait until the next license renewal period to report
D) Request an exemption from the DSPS
questions.explanation: Licensees must report convictions promptly to the DSPS.

questions.questionText: How can a firm demonstrate compliance with ADA accessibility requirements?
options: A) Provide only online services
B) Offer alternative methods to accommodate clients
C) Conduct annual DSPS inspections
D) Request ADA certification from the EEOC
questions.explanation: Firms must offer alternative methods if removing barriers is not feasible.

questions.questionText: What must a licensee do when terminating association with a firm?
options: A) Notify the DSPS using Form 766 within 10 days
B) Wait for the firm to report the termination
C) Submit a signed affidavit to the supervising broker
D) Immediately cease all real estate activities
questions.explanation: The licensee must notify the DSPS within 10 days.

questions.questionText: What happens to a firm’s licensees if the firm’s license is revoked?
options: A) They must stop providing brokerage services immediately
B) They can continue under independent practice agreements
C) They automatically transfer to another firm
D) They are only affected if involved in the violation
questions.explanation: Licensees must cease services if the firm’s license is revoked.

questions.questionText: What is required to alter a path of travel under ADA guidelines?
options: A) Full compliance with all accessibility standards
B) Proportional alterations if costs exceed 20% of the project
C) A court order mandating changes
D) No action unless specifically requested
questions.explanation: Path alterations must be proportional to the project’s cost if full compliance is infeasible.

questions.questionText: What is the penalty for a firm failing to review transaction documents before closing?
options: A) Suspension of the supervising broker’s license
B) Liability for errors and potential DSPS disciplinary action
C) Automatic revocation of the firm’s license
D) Inability to collect commissions from the transaction
questions.explanation: Failing to review documents can result in liability and DSPS action.

questions.questionText: What must be included in an independent contractor agreement?
options: A) A specific end date for the agreement
B) A statement clarifying non-employee tax status
C) A guarantee of health insurance coverage
D) A clause requiring hourly time tracking
questions.explanation: Agreements must clarify non-employee status for tax purposes.

questions.questionText: What should a transition plan include for pending transactions?
options: A) Contact information for all involved parties
B) Specific instructions for handling ongoing obligations
C) A schedule for client notifications
D) Termination dates for contracts
questions.explanation: Pending transactions must be addressed to avoid harm to clients.

questions.questionText: What legal doctrine is modified by Wis. Stat. § 452.139?
options: A) Negligence per se
B) Respondeat superior
C) Strict liability
D) Misrepresentation
questions.explanation: This statute modifies respondeat superior in real estate transactions.

questions.questionText: How should a firm handle client complaints about external service providers?
options: A) Guarantee the service provider’s work
B) Refer clients to a neutral resolution service
C) Clarify that the firm does not guarantee third-party services
D) Replace the service provider at the firm’s expense
questions.explanation: Firms must clarify that clients are responsible for verifying third-party services.

questions.questionText: What is the primary function of Schedule B-1 in a title insurance commitment?
options: A) Outline title insurance coverage limits
B) List requirements for closing
C) Identify exceptions to coverage
D) Provide a legal description of the property
questions.explanation: Schedule B-1 lists all requirements the parties must satisfy before closing.

questions.questionText: What is the legal requirement for firms offering accessibility services under the ADA?
options: A) Full barrier removal within five years
B) Reasonable efforts to provide accessible services
C) Automatic installation of ramps in all locations
D) No specific requirements apply to firms
questions.explanation: Firms must make reasonable efforts to provide access under the ADA.

questions.questionText: What must a firm do before closing a trust account?
options: A) Notify the DSPS within 15 days
B) Ensure all funds are disbursed or transferred
C) Submit a final audit to the DSPS
D) Obtain written approval from all clients
questions.explanation: A trust account cannot be closed until all funds are disbursed or transferred.

questions.questionText: How should a firm handle trust account funds from a rejected offer?
options: A) Retain the funds until further instructions
B) Deposit them in a temporary holding account
C) Return them to the payer or forward them to the payee within one business day
D) Transfer them to the firm’s operational account
questions.explanation: Funds from a rejected offer must be returned or forwarded promptly.

questions.questionText: What is the required action if a firm receives a non-depositable item as earnest money?
options: A) Hold it in the firm’s safe until the transaction closes
B) Deposit it in a separate non-depositable account
C) Return it to the buyer or direct them to an escrow agent
D) Convert it to a check and deposit in the trust account
questions.explanation: Firms cannot hold non-depositable items; parties must handle them separately.

questions.questionText: What must be included in the ledger for each transaction?
options: A) The supervising broker’s signature
B) A running balance, transaction details, and party names
C) Monthly reconciliations
D) The DSPS certification number for the trust account
questions.explanation: Ledgers must detail receipts, disbursements, and balances for each transaction.

questions.questionText: What does a title insurance policy protect against?
options: A) Market fluctuations
B) Defects, liens, or encumbrances in the title
C) Property damage
D) Zoning changes
questions.explanation: Title insurance ensures a clear and marketable title.

questions.questionText: What is the standard method of proration for real estate taxes?
options: A) Based on the seller's estimate
B) Divided equally between buyer and seller
C) Using the previous year’s tax bill as a reference
D) Calculated by the DSPS
questions.explanation: Parties typically use the previous year’s tax bill for proration.

questions.questionText: What is required to clear a construction lien exception?
options: A) A lien waiver from the seller
B) A gap endorsement purchased by the seller
C) A survey of the property
D) Proof of no outstanding taxes
questions.explanation: The gap exception is cleared with a gap endorsement.

questions.questionText: What must a firm do if it holds a promissory note related to a transaction?
options: A) Deposit it in the trust account
B) Record it in the ledger but not include it in the balance
C) Include it in the monthly trial balance
D) Send it to the DSPS for approval
questions.explanation: Promissory notes are recorded in the ledger but not included in the running balance.

questions.questionText: What action can a firm take if parties fail to agree on disbursing earnest money after 60 days?
options: A) Disburse funds at the firm's discretion
B) Retain the funds indefinitely
C) File an interpleader action or seek an attorney’s opinion
D) Transfer funds to the DSPS
questions.explanation: After 60 days, firms may seek legal resolution or an attorney's written opinion.

questions.questionText: What must a firm do before disbursing earnest money based on an attorney's opinion?
options: A) Obtain DSPS approval
B) Notify all parties by certified mail 30 days in advance
C) Ensure the opinion favors the firm
D) Have the attorney represent one of the parties
questions.explanation: Parties must receive 30 days' notice before disbursement based on an attorney's opinion.

questions.questionText: What can a firm do with trust account records if switching to computerized bookkeeping?
options: A) Retain paper records only for the past year
B) Ensure all entries are backed up daily on a separate medium
C) Submit records to the DSPS for review
D) Use manual systems alongside computerized methods
questions.explanation: Computerized records must have daily backups to comply with regulations.

questions.questionText: What must a firm do before disbursing earnest money based on an attorney's opinion?
options: A) Obtain DSPS approval
B) Notify all parties by certified mail 30 days in advance
C) Ensure the opinion favors the firm
D) Have the attorney represent one of the parties
questions.explanation: Parties must receive 30 days' notice before disbursement based on an attorney's opinion.

questions.questionText: What type of funds are not considered client funds under Wis. Stat. § 452.13?
options: A) Earnest money
B) Promissory notes
C) Security deposits for leases over one year
D) Down payments
questions.explanation: Promissory notes are not client funds as they are not liquid payments.

questions.questionText: What information is required when notifying the DSPS of a new trust account?
options: A) The firm owner’s name and license number
B) The account name, number, and depository institution
C) The anticipated annual balance
D) The firm’s total number of trust accounts
questions.explanation: Notification must include detailed account information and institution details.

questions.questionText: How should a firm handle escrow agreements for after-closing obligations?
options: A) Draft the agreement using a WB form
B) Refer the parties to an attorney
C) Hold the funds in the firm’s operational account
D) Use the standard REEB-approved after-closing escrow form
questions.explanation: Wisconsin does not approve a specific form for after-closing escrow agreements.
